subject: RE: [junit] Perform something before and after a complete test
msgSnippet: If you re relying on the GC to finalize your non-reachable classes so they release their valuable resource, you might want to change your design. In the case
messageBody:
If you're relying on the GC to finalize your non-reachable classes so they
release their valuable resource, you might want to change your design.

In the case where SomeClass does NOT hold a valuable resource, I have to
agree with JB : my tearDown is just smelly.



Thanks
--DP

-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
Sent: Saturday, June 05, 2004 3:50 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Perform something before and after a complete test


Neil Swingler wrote:

> > What is the advantage of the above code over the below code:
> >
> > private SomeClass thingBeingTested = new ThingBeingTested();
> >
> setUp is called when that test is run. All the TestCase class instances
are
> constructed when the suite is created so if you have 20 test methods, you
> will end up with 20 instances of ThingBeingTested existing concurrently
> which could be a problem if ThingBeingTested uses some valuable resource.

This is a great point, and it goes to show you that I never thought of
it because I'm able to avoid testing against such valuable resources
much of the time. Perhaps I need to test more legacy code. :)

> > In other words, do we EVER really need 'tearDown'? I do see the need
for
> > setUp, especially if you need to construct (horror) interlinked mock
> > objects. But why bother 'nulling' out your locals? They'll be GC'ed
> anyway,
> > right?
> >
> tearDown is analagous to finalize. You probably only need to use it to
> release some non memory resource e.g. close a connection, rollback a
> transaction., delete some temporary files

Yes. The only difference is that someone actually /invokes/
tearDown()... and you know /when/ it'll happen, especially if you use
the JUnit-addons test runner. :)
